passages.text: European Diversified Financials

Our August 2025 chartbook highlights another period of sector underperformance in comparison to the wider financial sub- sectors yet following H1 results. The sector's valuation discount is low vs history even as private capital exit activity remains limited and Al risks start to weigh more heavily.

Barclays Global Financial Services Conference in NYC, 8- 10 September: We will be hosting 11 European Diversified Financials management teams amongst the over 200 global financial corporate management teams
attending the conference in New York on 8- 10 September (see Conference agenda). We will be holding fireside chats

with LSEG CEO, David Schwimmer, Deutsche Boerse CEO, Stephan Leithner and Euronext CFO, Giorgio Modica. In addition, management teams will be holding investor one- on- one and small group meetings. Investor demand for company meetings is notably higher than 12 months ago. Themes are likely to vary across subsectors but we foresee a focus on 1) Al and technology risks in the exchanges and market infrastructure providers; 2) the potential for increased risk appetite among asset management and investment platform customers; 3) the realisation outlook for private capital participants.

Results in focus: \(>20\%\) performance dispersion in reaction through Q2/H1 results: With the whole sector coverage bar Pollen Street, reporting some financial data in late July/August, the one day results reaction (see Figure 5) has been quite extreme but evenly split. 13 stocks rose on reporting with the c.13% increase in Integrafin (Ow) the clear outperformer as it announced strong flows and a tighter cost framework; 11 stocks fell following financial disclosure with Amundi (EW) falling furthest at - 9% following its new revenue margin guidance.

Another month of in line with market performance extends underperformance vs the financial sub- sectors YTD: The majority of the sector coverage were flat or lower over the last month (see Figure 2) despite EPS upgrades being seen by most names over the last month (see Figure 10). As a result the sector maintained its broadly in line with the market performance year to date. This result leaves the sector now underperforming the Banking sector by nearly
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 13. Completed: 27- Aug- 25, 17:56 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 03:00 GMT Restricted - External
European Diversified Financials POSITIVE Unchanged
50% (vs 30% last month) and the Insurance sector by c.12% (vs 10% last month) YTD (see Figure 4).

Private capital activity shows signs of improvement: There was little evidence of a seasonal slowdown in activity in July with CLO issuance at or near peak volumes for 2025 in Europe (see Figure 14) and also in the US (see Figure 15), with CLO assets pricing higher (see Figure 16). These activity dynamics are likely to be supportive for the credit operations of ICG (OW) and CVC (OW). Alongside the greater CLO activity, investment deal activity by value was significantly higher month on month (see Figure 18) although deal volume remains subdued; the same was the case for exit activity which was also sharply higher month on month (see Figure 19) despite similar deal counts levels. With this supportive market data, the upcoming reporting from Partners Group (OW) and CVC is likely to provide some incremental commentary on the outlook here for the coming months.
FIGURE 1. Upcoming events and the European Diversified Financials sector

Reporting datesEvents2-SepPartners Group H1 25 results3-SepAvanza Monthly statistics for August3-SepNordnet Monthly statistics for August4-SepCVC H1 25 results5-SepAshmore FY25 results8-10 SepBarclays 23rd Annual Global Financial Services Conference25-Sep3i Capital Markets SeminarTBCPollen Street H1 25 results
Source: Company websites, Barclays Research

- Barclays Global Financial Services Conference: We host 11 European Diversified Financials management teams (either CEO or CFO) amongst the over 200 global financial corporate management teams attending the conference in New York on 8-10 September (see Conference agenda). Management teams will be holding investor one on one and small group meetings. Alongside we will host a number of fireside chats.

- CVC and Partners Group 
-H1 25 results: Following AUM activity updates, CVC and Partners Group are set to report their H1 financial results. We published a preview (NOTE LINK) where we anticipate >10% EBITDA growth YoY for both names but see limited scope for numerical surprise given the already disclosed AUM details. Focus will be on colour around existing fundraising and performance fee targets and in particular any realisation commentary.

- Ashmore (EW) 
-FY25 results: Having disclosed the AUM and exchange rate details (post Q4 25 note), Ashmore is set to report FY25 results next week. We forecast revenues c.23% lower YoY on declining average AUM, lower management fee margins and lower performance fees. With the FX headwind (due to USD depreciation) and revenues reduced more than costs, we forecast adj. EBITDA down by 24% YoY. Ashmore's historical commitment to the dividends means we expect Ashmore to keep DPS flat YoY (despite it no longer being covered by earnings). Focus will be colour around recent flow dynamics and the level of client interest around EM assets.

- Pollen Street (OW) 
-H1 results: Pollen Street will report H1 results that are likely to be well supported by a strong fundraising result for Private Equity V where there are reports (see link) that Pollen Street has raised €2bn by the final close of the fund. This was at the top end of its upsized target range and >85% above its prior vintage. With fees charged on committed capital and late management fees being earned on the fund, Pollen Street's management fees are likely to be well underpinned.
The following research reports gained the highest investor interest over the past month:
European Private Capital Managers: H1 preview - CVC and Partners Group (27/08/2025)
London Stock Exchange Group Plc: Post H1 update: Estimate trims but pipeline outlooks supportive, remain OW (01/08/2025)
3i Group PLC: Q1 26 NAV up \(7\%\) at 2,711p, supporting NAV upgrades; raise PT to 4710p (24/07/2025)
Schroders PLC: H1 25 results: Adj. op profit ahead as cost control evidenced; AUM \(1\%\) ahead (31/07/2025)
Man Group PLC: H1 25 result: performance fees and large mandate ensure flows, AUM and PBT ahead (30/07/2025)
Deutsche Boerse AG: Q2 25 Model update: Limited EPS trims on latest Treasury outlook (28/07/2025)
DWS Group: Post Q2 25: Raising FY25e EPS on Q2 beat and reiteration of targets (25/07/2025)
aberdeen: Post H1 25: EPS trimmed for future years (04/08/2025)
Amundi SA: Post Q2 25: lower revenue margin mix, lower earnings estimates (04/08/2025)
Allfunds Group PLC: H1 25 results: Better flows/AUA but PBT below and a small guidance trim (29/07/2025)
AJ Bell PLC: Post- 3Q25 update: Strong D2C performance and MTM drive EPS upgrades (28/07/2025)
Jupiter Fund Management: Post H1 25: Resetting estimates for CCLA and market levels, remain UW (28/07/2025)

The attached monthly chartbook includes chart details and key indicators on both the overall sector and the individual sub- sectors. From the chartbook, we highlight a selection of charts that contain details that are particularly relevant for the current month.

Traditional asset management sector in July: EU net inflows softened on weaker inflows into Bond products and Active Funds; UK net outflows re- accelerated on higher outflows from Equity products and Passive Funds

In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative (see definitions below). A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system. Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.
Below is the list of companies that constitute the "industry coverage universe":

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.
